Line 70: Line 70:
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of reproduction. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate=[[2007-06-17]]|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, since praying mantids have two or more brains within the whole of their bodies, with only one of these being in the head, the male could still be said to be alive even after decapitation, and so necrophilia may not be an entirely appropriate term in this case.<ref name="How Big">{{Cite web|url=http://www.madsci.org/posts/archives/aug98/898273575.Zo.r.html|title=How big is a praying mantis brain and how smart is it?|accessdate=[[2007-06-17]]|publisher=MadSci Network|year=1998|author=Thomas M. Greiner}}</ref>
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of reproduction. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate=[[2007-06-17]]|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, since praying mantids have two or more brains within the whole of their bodies, with only one of these being in the head, the male could still be said to be alive even after decapitation, and so necrophilia may not be an entirely appropriate term in this case.<ref name="How Big">{{Cite web|url=http://www.madsci.org/posts/archives/aug98/898273575.Zo.r.html|title=How big is a praying mantis brain and how smart is it?|accessdate=[[2007-06-17]]|publisher=MadSci Network|year=1998|author=Thomas M. Greiner}}</ref>
  +   +
See also [[Davian behavior]].
